comments.commentBody: And I'm an old white male in Idaho who is appalled at Chuck Winder and this state's near-dictatorship by the GOP.  We need more Liberals to move to our otherwise beautiful state and reclaim the government.
What type of woman marries these men?
@Linda.  In a word, misogyny.

I cannot bear to see what the right wants to do to women in this country. When I read Chuck Winder's words about why he should invade women's bodies with his law, I was floored. He questioned whether women understand when they've been raped. What is going on that the Republicans want to treat women like unruly children?  What is going on with the constant insults that women don't know enough about their own bodies to make their own decisions. Freedom to the Republicans means freedom if you are an old, white, male. Nobody else needs freedom in GOP country.
Yup. And those earth tremors in Wisconsin? Obama's fault.

"This claim isn’t just nuts; it’s a sort of craziness triple play — a lie wrapped in an absurdity swaddled in paranoia. " [Krugman]

Very aptly put, Paul !

When will the Republicans start blaming Obama for the weather and hurricanes?

[Oh, I forgot they've started that: Climate change, a baloney !]

Tyranny is an excellent word for what is happening. ALEC and the Catholic bishops are in league to re-establish white, male supremacy. What they are doing is an insult of the first order. They will attack voting rights (minorities), immigration, gay rights, and women's rights as autonomous human beings. They will also attempt to make doctors agents of the state performing unethical forced rape. (That will teach all those M.D.s who think they are so smart!) All the while, behind our outraged backs they will manipulating financial markets and skimming off military contracts while taking back (government financed) underwater mortgages, letting the present homeowners rent (and jacking up those rents) until the housing market improves. Then, they get to make even more money by dumping the renters and selling the houses at a profit. A deal made in heaven, or at least Washington, where the banks get no risk and plenty of taxpayer money to make even more money later.

Yes, no accountability at all. Accountability is a word that only applies to the little people, and we are rapidly all becoming littler and littler.
Both parties are really just shams created in 50 different flavors by state legislatures.

Even though I believe that the fact that Santorum is now considered a legitimate candidate within the Republican Party is an abomination, it is about time that we had an election where the vision of what America should stand for could not be clearer. It is time for America’s voters to decide what kind of country they want.

Do we want an America where Santorum’s conservative ideas rule the day?

Are we really committed to President Obama’s change doctrine?

We certainly could not have two more different views of America and the world. We could not have two more different views about freedom and privacy, war and peace, or the role of government in a modern society.

For me, the choice is really simple; I hope these two views of the world finally confront each other and give the electorate a chance to resolve this conflict once and for all.

David:
You were apparently in some alternative universe during the midterm 2010 elections. In the real world, the Democrat party, at the local, state and national levels had losses of historic proportions not seen in four decades. Even liberals (excuse me, "progressives) don't believe Republicans will take "a drubbing of historic proportions", simply because many more Democrat seats are in play than Republican and recent redistricting favors more Republicans. I would suggest you prepare yourself for a Republican House and Senate at the least.

Really, what can we say anymore about this party? I used to think of it as one of our two "great" parties, even though I disagreed with them. What a joke. (The Democrats aren't that great either, of course.)

Can these guys beat Obama? Probably not, but there's always a chance. Events could turn in such a way that anything is possible. There is a much greater chance that they will take a drubbing of historic proportions. It would be about time is all I can say. The Republican Party has sought to make itself less and less relevant with each passing election and each passing year. They've become a party of angry, threatened white guys, of cranks, nut cases, holly rollers, and ignoramuses.

And here's the irony. If Romney does lose, what will they do? They'll say they lost because they nominated a moderate, and that they need to go hardcore conservative in the future.

Amazing and sad.
Romney expects all good people to drop dead for him.

Your final statement bears repeating loud and often. Mr. Romney, if he knows better, needs to do better by appealing to people's better angels, rather than entertaining, even sanctioning their deep seated conceptions.

A wise man once said, evil thrives when good men do nothing. Unless, of course, Romney is no good man.

What a great comment!   I agree with your penultimate paragraph that there is no honest discussion about energy.  I applaud you for adding data to the discussion.   However, I would contest that Obama supporting alternative energy has had any major effect on the public other than the usual political grist around Solyndra.  I would also suggest that saber rattling by Congress or presidential candidates in addition to market speculation and the diminished value of the dollar are much more of cause.  But as you have mentioned, there is no honest discussion.  Nor do I believe there will be after the Nov. election.

is UNLOOSEN sorta like inflammable?

I can see it from UNLOOSE/UNLEASH I guess ...

The late NYT assistant managing editor Theodore M. Bernstein, in his wonderful book "The Careful Writer," said about flammable, "[fire underwriters] argue—and no doubt with justice—that non-philologists in the population, on picking up a can of cleaning fluid labeled inflammable, believe the fluid will not burn and may thus be compelled to learn philology the hard way."

Welcome to WP Steven Riley and way to go, getting your initial puzzle in the NYT. I liked UNLOOSEN, deriving a nautical tack from the clue. The sleeping w/fishes clue, the clam reference or JERSEY SHORE had me in a dock of the bay frame of mind. I'll be shoving off for now.
YOURS,
Bru
Nobody in their right mind ventures where Mr. Obama went without the committed backing of a score of billionaires.

I give major kudos to folks who run for office and really believe in public service.  When Barack Obama first ran for President I often expressed amazement about him doing it as the economy was in a free-fall, America was fighting 2 wars, and the debt was ballooning.  It's one thing not to acknowledge someone successes.  The surge of troops in Iraq toward the end of Bush's administration was a success but President Obama and the Democrats don't acknowledge it.  However, they don't flat out lie and say the surge was a huge failure...or that the withdrawal of US troops would have occurred just as well with the surge.  This is the big difference between the leaders of the parties.  Seeing prominent Republicans deny all positive accomplishments of the Obama administration (e.g., Osama bin Laden, positive job growth) while attributing all negative news to the same administration makes them seem incredibly foolish, petty, and small.  It also makes me long for a true 2-party political system in the United States.  I've been a registered independent voter for more than 30 years but I haven't had a reason to cast a ballot for a Republican in a federal election for a very, very long time.  For a political party, constant denial is NOT a good thing.

Perhaps the Israeli fear is that the Mullahs are willing to sacrifice their own people while the Israeli leaders are not.  This is possibly not a valid fear in the case of Iran, but Israel has seen its enemies use their own people as human shields and human bombs repeatedly in the past.  From this perspective, it will be hard to convince them that an Iranian bomb would be benign.
The Republicans are clearly prepared to sacrifice us to defeat Mr. Obama.
The pirates do not threaten anyone's existence. A very poor analogy.

One other possibility: we can simply stop pretending that Israel doesn't have a nuclear arsenal of its own and bear in mind that a nuclear-armed Iran would have no chance of surviving for five minutes if it went ahead and bombed Israel.  As far asTehran being a threat to the U.S., we have more to fear from Somali pirates than we do from malevolent mullahs.  Earth to Washington: Jews use oil, too.

To all experienced salesmen who made top dollar peddling in private enterprise, supply side economics is the biggest crock of manure ever invented. Demand is what drives capitalism. Once there is demand, somebody will figure out how to supply it.

The Republican Party is suffering from 30 years of catastrophic success.

30 years ago when we suffered from stagflation, supply side policies made some sense. After 10 year's they made no sense. By 1999, we reached the saturation point. By 2008, they caused a sudden, massive collapse in demand - demand that had only been sustained by cheap and easy credit.

Conditions have changed - we don't suffer from a lack of supply, we suffer from a lack of demand. Supply side policies benefit the rich, so Republicans can only support supply side policies. Because Republicans can only support supply side bias, it means thei policies can only inflict massive damage upon the country.

What's true about Republican economic policies, is generally true about all of their policies. They've been so successful at implementing them that they've become played and counter productive.

Because Republican victories bring only policy failure, they have had to "politicized" facts.

They use their media wall and message discipline to pass this false reality on to their base. Here is where Romney has an edge.

Romney is a graduate of Bain Capital. Bain executives universally back their old colleague. Bain Capital owns a huge percentage of Clear Channel. Clear Channel writes Rush Limbaugh's massive pay check. Right now, with Limbaugh losing sponsors, he's more dependent upon Clear Channel's kindness than normal. Which means expect message discipline more than normal while Romney himself fluctuates
I'm sorry, Jack. I too fail to see how you draw your conclusion from the argument you make. You speak of inflation, you catalogue a decade of ills and then somehow sneak in Obama.

Romney is trying to come clean on yet another self-inflicted wound, Ed. Sorry, but the President had NOTHING to do with it.

But you must agree that Romney WILL win on the delegate count, not inevitability. So relax. Santorum is twice the liar Romney is. And Gingrich may not quit but you can stick a fork in him -- he is absolutely, completely done.

Two Washington politicians, Santorum and Gingrich, holding a child's toy in their hands, in an effort to bring down the man they could not beat in the normal routine of the Republica primaries.

These two Washington politicians, have been there, played the politics of their time, learned the tricks first hand, how to debase your opposition...now Mitt Romney is their target.

Santorum and Gingrich could not make it in Washington, as others have, to their retirement. They were both ousted...Gingrich, by his fellow Republicans in the House, Santorum, rejected by his constituents.

It is now, there is hope of a new leader emerging to replace a failed President Obama, that Gov. Romney is still being attacked by the two...each one knowing they do not have a chance to beat Romney.

Why?

There is but one answer...they are Washington politicians...bred in Washington, as a self-survival animal...emphasis on "self". There are many that quietly leave Washington with respect and honor, after serving. It is a few, like Santorum and Gingrich that do not know when to quit.

Two Washigton politicians, making it hard for change to happen.

is UNLOOSEN sorta like inflammable?

I can see it from UNLOOSE/UNLEASH I guess ...

His Iran policy? You must mean AIPAC and Netanyahu, cause Obama is pursuing a diplomatic solution. Oh, I know; it's Congress. Remember those sanctions they imposed on Iran and anyone who does business with Iran?

In the first place, the etch-a-sketch comment by Romney's aid was not a gaffe, it was the fundamental premise of his campaign, namely that he will say anything, do anything, spend any amount to tarnish the image of America's first Black president. Lying is okay. Character assassination is okay. Flip-flopping is okay. That is what the Republican base wants to hear. That is the essential truth they respond to. How can anyone even doubt it. The Republican Party has been smearing the President at the expense of America, since the instant of his inauguration, and it is okay, because Republicans have three obsessions which must be fed on a daily basis. They love guns, they hate women and they hate minorities. It all comes down to that. It isn't a question of climate change, deficit reduction, tax policy, health care, it is about bigotry. It always has been and it always will be. It boils down to the basest human instinct which is a desire to subjugate another human being because you believe you are better. The truth is the first casualty in a civilization gone awry. Next is the legal system, the destruction of government infrastructure and finally class warfare. How far along are we. I'll tell you next November.
Sadly true

" In 2008, 46.3 percent of potential drivers 19 years old and younger had drivers’ licenses, compared with 64.4 percent in 1998, according to the Federal Highway Administration, and drivers ages 21 to 30 drove 12 percent fewer miles in 2009 than they did in 1995."

Is this a marketing problem alone, or is it also related to (a) the dwindling middle-class (b) rise in fuel prices when compared to 1998, and (c) online shopping?

I may have missed it but when was the President "pushing solar energy" to fuel automobiles?  Your analysis about the CPI has absolutely nothing to do with the price of gasoline.   Try reading Samuelson (Econ 101).  It is a very simple matter, as Professor Krugman points out, of supply and demand.  Worldwide demand has gone up and up (see the EIA for the data) and the OPEC cartel continues to limit supply (read the news) and keep the price high.  Other producers, including us, are unable to fill the void because we don't have sufficient reserves and those that we do have are very expensive to produce.  We pumped all the cheap stuff long ago.  The drain America first policy advocated by Moe, Larry and Curly (Romney, Santorum and Gingrich), will not affect the price in any significant way either in the short or long term.  We should keep OUR oil around to fuel our military needs and other essential needs into the future.  As the worldwide economy continues to improve, the price of oil is going to get higher, and higher, and higher because demand will continue to rise and OPEC will continue to mete out its abundant oil in a way to keep the price high.  Better fill up those bicycle tires.

...and there is already a published solution.

Make the photo a Progressive JPEG, and it will display in glorious full res.
So you're saying the new iPad is not too good for the web.
There is a work around, problem is its a new thing. Lets give companies a few months to catch up, it will happen but it takes time.

Everyone here including the author of this article is failing to realize that the new iPad down samples all web images regardless of their native resolution. If you try to view an image larger than two megapixels on the iPad it will shrink it. I went to the Canon website to view sample images from their new 5D Mark III that were over 5000 pixels and they show up on the newiPad retina display as 1440 x 960 pixels.

This is a known issue and comments are starting to fill the Apple support forums.
The law of diminution at the margin defines all of economics: the more of anything you have, the less each unit of it is worth to you.

Thank you Dr. Krugman for reminding us all that oil production is a global business.

Any economics 101 student would understand in a minute why oil prices have been going up. World production has been rising slowly, but demand has been rising at a faster rate because of rapid economic development in Asia. The basic law of supply and demand dictates that prices should be going up as a result, and they have.

A somewhat disheartening fact is that, in the past decade, US oil production has likewise been going up, while domestic demand has been stable or dropping (thanks in part to better fuel efficiency). If oil prices were determined locally, gas should have thus become cheaper... This is probably what the critics fail to understand; it is world supply and demand that really counts, and there's nothing much the US can do about it. This point needs to be hammered in.

This is true only so long as our economic system isn't fundamentally an extractive system concentrating wealth and income in the hands of those at the top.

Unfortunately, income growth and wealth have been pooling at the top for decades now, so just working harder and smarter at our jobs may not bring back solid growth.
Your plutocracy appears committed to rewarding the worst sociopaths among you most extravagantly.

OCCUPY- your mind, the streets, the statehouses, the city halls, everywhere - Words have become meaningless in this Orwellian babble of the right. The only way to make yourself understood is to present a demonstration of force through numbers. The right will scream mob rule, and dirty hippies, but they are already frightened by the scary tales they've been fed by the opportunistic demagogues, the politicians. Protest, demonstrate ( take a hint from Wisconsin)- Occupy !
All advertising funded media is more concerned about keeping advertisers than reporting facts honestly.

Good, we need you to identify specific media personalities that spread gop destructive fantasies, every week on TV on shows that are mainstream, high status, and well regarded by middle America. They hear this misleading paranoia week after week and figure if it’s on the main network’s news shows, it can’t be too far out. But it is.
They don’t have to be Fox News watchers to get a steady diet of this drivel. They only have to watch the networks and CNN. our mainstream, entrenched, so called objective media, that try to present each side equally.

Except they don’t—their conservative pundits have grown more boldly, irrationally right wing each year. The so called moderates go along, and the progressives don’t know how to fight back—or don’t want to be too aggressive lest they lose their media gig. TV punditry has let our political discussion get so irrational that voters have been molded in their opinions to accept the unacceptable. The lie that govt is bad is the worst. Thus our country keeps going backward as the quality of our candidates goes downward.

We are in 2012, but we seem to be in the 1950s or 60s, or earlier in so many areas—in our lowering standard of living, union busting, poor education, the war against womens' health, social security/medicare, and in the racial problems that remind us of black 2nd class citizenship of decades ago.

Keep naming names of politicians and pundits who claim to be speaking for all of us, but who are dragging the country down.

John, My thoughts immediately shot to both you and Leapy's back-to-back comments from yesterdays puzzle, you with Riley, and she with Wryly! hahahaha

Howie

Henry Ford, for all his faults, understood the principle that a Ford employee should be paid enough to buy a Ford car. When corporations had massive layoffs, they cut costs, but also eroded their customer base. GMs prospective buyers may have lost years of long term savings, and will lose many more as long as interest rates are held down to benefit corporate expansion. The result is that a new car is no longer a realistic aspiration.

Unless we can revive a middle class economy, it will be meaningless to try to sell cars as objects of desire.

Exactly right, P&I, and it seemed to fit the bill for MOL's comment. I should've included the citation, not having meant to pass it off as my own.  Both Parker and Hepburn are on my A-List, so I disagree with her observation, although the comment is perfectly crafted. In one of her biographies "You Might As Well Dance", you'll find her infamous "You can lead a horticulture, but you can't make her think", as well as the information that she called her canary Onan, because he spilled his seed upon the ground...
Priceless, Leapy.  That's a Parker quote I didn't know. (The horticulture one, I mean). Worth scrolling thru all the comments for sure.

suejean, you might be able to find the book. The corrected title is "You Might as Well LIVE". Includes a sprightly poem about different methods of committing suicide...despite her famous wit, did not enjoy her life all that much

I sailed through this clockwise thinking "Jeez, easy Friday," until I came to a dead stop back on the left coast (south of BRAIN FREEZE, though... checking the map, it was around Sacramento).  So, Jeez.  Which reminds me, I turn LX on Easter Sunday.  Which reminds me of the e-card I sent my sister (for her LXI-th); it said "Age is just a number that determines how happy, attractive and able-bodied you are."  Just awful, but back to the puzzle.  I loved most of it, but I don't see YOURS as a likely alternative to "cheers."  And never heard of the MAGIC SQUARE.  Magic Triangle, yes (see "Donald [Duck] in Mathmagic Land").  I have friends named Archer with four-letter first names, thus could not come up with ANNE.  Lovely woman, but now I am picturing poached bunny.  Easter Bunny.  Jeez.
